narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: historical and model of sociology methods

I learned a lot about the policymaking establishment in the US and how to think about policy in a systematic way. Prof. Boorman's experience in the field gave him a lot of annectdotes to share which illustrated many of the concepts.
We learned to view complex social phenomena and social policy tools through both an applied-historical lens, as well as with a formal modeling lens.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strenghts: Prof. Boorman is extremely knowledgeable and extremely invested in his students. He would constantly offer to meet 1on1 to discuss topics that interested us, and was always willing to take questions and engage with our interventions. The readings are also not that hard and distill some interesting concepts that, even if they might seem pointless at first, you quickly understand their value to understand and evaluate policy. The class is also very organized around table 6.1 and leaves you with a solid baggage to use in the future

Cons: Lectures could be better organized. Although Prof. Boorman's tangents and anecdotes are interesting, I felt like some of the more technical content (both historical and mathematical) could have been covered more thoroughly if these tangents were kept shorter.

The movements between historical and formal mathematical analysis is not something that I would change, but it is certainly not for everyone, so students should be aware that this is the case before deciding to enroll.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Since the class was a lecture it worked well with minimal adjustements.
I enjoyed the live lecture format, and the email installments provided by the professor.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you are interested in policy, absolutely! You won't get such a practical course on the subject anywhere else at Yale.

Yes. If you take this course seriously, you will appreciate the complexity of the world in which you live in a whole new way. I know that sounds like a cliche, but it is true. The only caveat I would offer is that the "vision" the course supplies is one that you may not resonate with. But if you do, it will be an excellent experience. Also, Professor Boorman may be the smartest man I have ever met, and this shines through in the class.
